utterance: Unfortunately, Sophie, not long. I took a look at your test results, and it seems like the cancer has spread. Likely, we're talking about a matter of months at this point. Maybe up to a year.
rewritten: Your prognosis is that you will likely live for some months to a year.

utterance: That depends on what your goals are, Sophie. If you want to try to prolong your life, we can try putting you on aggressive chemotherapy, but typically that has a lot of side effects. It could make you very sick. The other option would be palliative care or hospice, where we try to treat your pain and make sure you're able to spend valuable time with your family in the time you have left.
rewritten: Your treatment options are aggressive chemotherapy or palliative care.

context: What do my test results show?
utterance: Unfortunately, it seems like you're not going to make it.
rewritten: Your test results indicate a poor prognosis.

context: Are there any other treatments available?
rewritten: There are no other treatments available.

context: Your treatment options are aggressive chemotherapy or palliative care.
utterance: I don't really know much about either of those. What would you recommend?
rewritten: Which treatment option do you recommend?

utterance: What's most important to you, Sophie?
How much do you understand so far?
rewritten: How much do you currently understand about your prognosis?
